required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Treatment of Postoperative Urinary Retention - WHAT DO WOMEN WANT?

brief_summary.textblock: This study investigates patient's preference and satisfaction with choice of catheterization after surgical urogynecological procedures.

detailed_description.textblock: Preoperatively, the enrolled patient receives information about risks and benefits of three ways of bladder catheterization as means of management of postoperative urinary retention. Based on this information, the patient chooses her preferred way of postoperative catheterization in case she experiences acute urinary retention after surgery. After the surgery, those patients requiring catheterization postoperatively evaluate their experience in a postoperative questionnaire.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Insufficient enrollment, question addressed by other researchers

primary_outcome.measure: Patient satisfaction with choice of catheterization method

secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of complication rates between intermittent vs. indwelling catheterization: data derived from review of participant medical record

study_pop.textblock: Adult women presenting to the urogynecology offices at NorthShore University HealthSystem with a urogynecologic diagnosis desiring surgical management.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All female patients who undergo urogynecological surgery procedures at NorthShore University HealthSystem and consent to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who cannot read, comprehend, and write in English
